==Prevention==
  â   â
The key to any good Retail Loss Prevention strategy is to focus on "prevention" rather than "loss". Being proactive and getting ahead of offenders and problem areas will dramatically reduce profit loss. Many strategies are low cost and highly effective when properly deployed.
  â   â
Here is a list of some of the things Retailers can do to focus on prevention.
  â
:* Employee training, focus on excellent customer service, a proven strategy to reduce losses both externally and internally.
  â
# Develop a customer service program that includes methods of approaching customers and offering service-include a section on dealing with suspicious people
  â
# Include a section on staff education-employees with knowledge and understanding of the issues are more able and likely to help with prevention
  â
# Make employees feel safe-ensure staff know what to do if they feel threatened or intimidated in any situation.
  â
# Clearly define what employees can do if they feel another employee may be doing something wrong - such as stealing cash or inventory.
  â
# Follow up with staff on issues and incidents, acknowledge staff members who come up with ideas or who's actions helped to prevent loss
  â

  â   â
:* Create ongoing awareness by conducting meetings, appointing a comittee and or a "Loss Prevention Champion or Leader" (this would be in addition to any professional or full time dedicated Loss Prevention personnel). Also have regular announcements, posters or other reminders regarding Loss Prevention issues, this serves to keep things "top of mind" with employees.
  â   â
:* Seek out help and act quickly on problems. Utilize resources such as Local Law Enforcement, Private Investigators, and Loss Prevention Consultants when necessary. Ignoring potential problems-particularly those around employee theft will only result in making things worse and increasing loss. Seldom do problems just go away, turn a blind eye at your own peril!
  â
:* Being proactive rather than reactive is the best approach. A small investment up front can potentially result in substantial reductions in loss. Catching is always more costly than prevention.
